titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Norman Douglas Papers LSC.0111
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Manuscripts Division staff, February 1962; machine-readable finding aid created by Caroline Cub√©.

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-08-01 16:19:14 -0700.

did.unittitle: Norman Douglas papers
did.abstract: George Norman Douglas (1868-1952) was a British author, scientist, diplomat, and editor. The collection consists of correspondence, manuscripts, corrected proofs, and notebooks related to Douglas' early scientific interests and literary career.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Reproduction and Use
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.
Copyright of unpublished letters by Norman Douglas is owned by the author's estate and represented by the Society of Authors, 84 Drayton Gardens, London, SW10 9SB.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Norman Douglas Papers (Collection 111). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.
Processed by Manuscripts Division staff, February 1962.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

odd.head: UCLA Catalog Record ID
odd.p: We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: George Norman Douglas was born December 8, 1868 in Falkenhorst, Thuringen, Austria; recognized as British author, scientist, diplomat, and editor; began writing career composing zoological texts while in foreign service; published first work of fiction, Unprofessional tales (1901), under pseudonym Normyx; contributor and assistant editor, English review; best known as novelist and travel writer; greatest American success was with novel, South wind (1917); other novels and publications include Siren land (1911), Old Calabria (1928), Looking back (1933), Late harvest (1946); died on the island of Capri, 1952.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of correspondence, manuscripts, corrected proofs, and notebooks related to Douglas' early scientific interests and literary career. The bulk of the papers cover his literary career, and correspondents include: Martha Gordon Croutch, Richard Curle, Robin Douglas, Leon Gelber, Frank Harris, William Henry Hudson, Edward Hutton, Frieda Lawrence, Walter Lowenfels, Giuseppe Oriolo, Grant Richards, Martin Secker, Montague Sumners, Reginald Turner, and others. Material related to Douglas's scientific interests (1879-1905) includes correspondence with Georg Albert Boulenger, Albert Girtanner, James Edmund Harting, Franz von Leydig, Hugh Alexander MacPherson, and Margherita Traube-Mengarini.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in the following series:
Correspondence (Boxes 1-5).
Manuscripts, notebooks, proofs, clippings, photographs, typescripts, and ephemera (Boxes 6-8, 17).
Limited editions of some of Douglas's works (Box 9).
Books from Douglas' library (Boxes 10-17).

did.unittitle: Correspondence

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The guide should be consulted for greater details, keeping in mind that the grouping has been greatly altered, as indexed here:

Manuscripts, Ephemera, and Books

odd.head: General note
odd.p: For detailed descriptions of the manuscripts, ephemera, and books contained in Boxes 6-9, the earlier guide should be consulted. This an index to the revised grouping. Boxes 1-5 contain the correspondence: grouping also revised.

did.unittitle: Autobiographical materials: extracts from notebooks, letters.
Correspondence, ephemera re emigration of Norman Douglas to the United States. v.p.,
[De natura hominis] n.p.,
Disiecta membra: materials for a description of Capri.
Index [to the Capri monographs]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Proof copy for the edition of 100 copies issued 1913. Heavily annotated throughout in the author's hand and with his initials on page 333. This index, the last pamphlet of the Capri series, was issued for private distribution. Original red wrappers inscirbed "Press N.D." In a grey buckram folding case, red morocco label, gilt.

did.unittitle: Douglas Calendar - index, correspondence with agents.
Ephemera - clippings, etc.
List of important people in case of death. 1952(?).
Material (on coloration of bird-eggs)
Notebooks, Germany and England, (On natural science).
A plea for the German professor. n.p., during World War I.
Scientific ephemera: maps, notes, clippings, drawings.
Theophilus, or They went. Author's explantion.
Tribulations of a patriot. n.p., (during World War I) clipped article.
Portraits, photographs of Norman, Robin Douglas, etc.
In the beginning (Florence, 1927) 4 signatures, unbound.
Last of the Medici (introduction)
Late harvest. London,
Table showing the results of an examination.
Theophilus. (Dramatization) n.p.,
Venus in the kitchen by Pilaff Bey. n.p.,
Woolf, Cecil. [Bio-bibliography of Norman Douglas, n.p.,
An almanac, version corrected for press. Portugal,
did.physdesc: Typescript with holograph introduction. Red slip-case.

did.unittitle: Alone. (Earlier manuscript). n.p.,
Alone. Index to manuscript. Florence,
Fountains in the sand, First and quite different version.
The familiar spirit. n.p.,

did.unittitle: South Wind

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Proof-sheets for the 1945 Secker edition, marked with revisions by Douglas' friend, William King.

did.unittitle: The Life of the Venerable Suor Serafina Di Dio: with notes bibiographical and historical

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Presentation copy to S. E. Brooks, signed by the author and with corrections in his hand. Limited edition of 100 copies.

did.unittitle: Group IV Books from the Library of Norman Douglas

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Some of the books are plated with the armorial Douglas bookplate, some of them have N. Douglas' early signature on fly-leaf (G.N. Douglas), later purchases bear the rubber-stamp book-mark N.D.

Douglas, Norman. Looking back. New York, Harcourt, Brace & Company, 1 p.l., 135 leaves. Galley proofs, uncorrected. 15 illustrations are listed in the galleys, but only 8 were published.

___ Together. n.p., 102 pages. Holograph manuscript (incomplete) with copious corrections and additions. This is apparently the first draft. pp.103-178 missing (sections titled Valduna, Old Anna, and Schlins.) With this: Notes used for writing Together, pp.179-192.
